verses.text: I have made a covenant with my eyes; how then could I look lustfully at a young woman?
verses.comment: Job begins by declaring his purity and self-control, reminiscent of Christ’s teaching on the heart’s purity (see Matthew 5:28). The image of a covenant reveals the seriousness of intentional discipline over one's thoughts.

verses.text: For what would be the portion from God above, and the heritage from the Almighty on high?
verses.comment: Job refers to divine recompense. God’s ultimate authority and judgment is at the root of moral integrity.

verses.text: Is not disaster for the unjust, and calamity for those who do wrong?
verses.comment: Job sees divine justice as inherent to God’s governance of the world; this rationale is echoed throughout the wisdom literature.

verses.text: Does He not see my ways and count all my steps?
verses.comment: God’s omniscience and intimate knowledge of man recalls Psalm 139 and spiritual vigilance in the journey towards perfection.

verses.text: If I have walked with falsehood, or my foot has hurried to deceit,
verses.comment: Job invites close scrutiny of his life, echoing the call to personal accountability found in the Psalms.

verses.text: let God weigh me in honest scales, so that He may know my integrity.
verses.comment: The request for God’s judgment anticipates the theme of final judgment—a key reality in the faith.

verses.text: If my step has turned away from the path, or my heart followed my eyes, or if my hands have been stained,
verses.comment: Job identifies the heart and actions as both necessary for true righteousness, which is later fulfilled in the Gospel’s call to interior conversion.

verses.text: then may another eat what I have sown, and may my crops be uprooted.
verses.comment: Job offers a curse upon himself if he is guilty—a parallel to Old Testament covenant curses.

verses.text: If my heart has been enticed by a woman, or if I have lain in wait at my neighbor’s door,
verses.comment: Job addresses adultery as an offense against both God and man’s neighbor, showing covenantal fidelity.

verses.text: then let my wife grind for another, and let other men kneel over her.
verses.comment: A severe self-imposed curse revealing Job’s adamant rejection of infidelity, closely tied to the sanctity of marriage.

verses.text: For that would be a disgraceful act, an iniquity to be judged.
verses.comment: Job understands adultery as a ‘great sin’ (Genesis 39:9), reflecting both moral and communal dimensions of sin.

verses.text: It is a fire that consumes to Abaddon; it would root out all my increase.
verses.comment: Sexual immorality is depicted with destructive imagery, anticipating later teachings on the seriousness of sin.

verses.text: If I have rejected the cause of my male or female servants when they brought a complaint against me,
verses.comment: Job’s justice extends to all under his care, reflecting the dignity of all persons—parallels with New Testament concern for the weak (James 5:4).

verses.text: what then shall I do when God rises up? When He calls me to account, what will I answer Him?
verses.comment: The imagery of future judgment and accountability foreshadows the scene of Christ at the final judgment.

verses.text: Did not He who made me in the womb make them? Did not the same One form us both within our mothers?
verses.comment: Job’s recognition of the Creator’s work in all humans underpins the deep unity of the human family.

verses.text: If I have withheld anything the poor desired, or caused the eyes of the widow to fail,
verses.comment: Charity towards the poor is a constant theme, a prefiguration of Christ’s preaching on generosity and compassion.

verses.text: or eaten my morsel alone, and the fatherless has not eaten of it—
verses.comment: Job’s sharing is a practical manifestation of love of neighbor, supported by the prophets.

verses.text: for from my youth I brought him up as with a father, and from my mother’s womb I have guided the widow—
verses.comment: The lifelong practice of charity is elevated as an ideal—foreshadowing the perfection of virtue found in the saints.

verses.text: if I have seen anyone perish for lack of clothing, or the poor without covering,
verses.comment: Job anticipates the corporal works of mercy enjoined by Christ in the New Testament.

verses.text: if his body has not blessed me, and he was not warmed with the fleece of my sheep,
verses.comment: Job refers to the reciprocal blessings of charity; giving brings gratitude and blessing—even prefiguring the concept of grace.

verses.text: if I have raised my hand against the fatherless, because I saw my help in the gate,
verses.comment: He denies ever abusing his power to oppress the oppressed—a standard for righteous authority.

verses.text: then let my shoulder fall from its socket, and my arm be broken from its bone.
verses.comment: Another self-imposed curse, signifying Job’s confidence in his justice—a willingness to submit to the consequences of sin.

verses.text: For disaster from God was a terror to me, and because of His majesty I could not do such things.
verses.comment: A healthy ‘fear of God’ motivates moral living; awe and reverence are vital components of the spiritual life.

verses.text: If I have put my trust in gold or called fine gold my security,
verses.comment: Idolatry of riches is firmly denied—Job chooses trust in God, not in wealth.

verses.text: if I have rejoiced because my wealth was great, or because my hand had gotten much,
verses.comment: Job resists pride in temporal successes, which is repeated in later prophetic and apostolic warnings.

verses.text: if I have looked at the sun when it shined, or the moon moving in brightness,
verses.comment: Rejection of idolatry and worship of creation—Job maintains exclusive devotion to the Creator.

verses.text: and my heart has been secretly enticed, or my mouth has kissed my hand—
verses.comment: ‘Kissed my hand’ refers to an act of idolatrous worship—a subtle warning about even hidden idolatry.

verses.text: this also would be an iniquity to be judged, for I would have denied God above.
verses.comment: Any worship besides God is a denial of Him, anticipating the monotheism perfectly fulfilled in later revelation.

verses.text: If I have rejoiced at the ruin of him who hated me, or have been glad when evil overtook him—
verses.comment: Job’s refusal to gloat shows the imperative of loving enemies, a teaching perfected by Christ.

verses.text: I have not allowed my mouth to sin by asking for a curse on his life—
verses.comment: This echoes the New Testament: 'Bless those who persecute you.' Morality extends to both deed and word.

verses.text: if the people of my tent have not said, 'Who can find one who has not been filled with Job’s meat?'
verses.comment: Job’s household attests to his hospitality; a moral example of open-handedness.

verses.text: The sojourner has not lodged in the street; I have opened my doors to the traveler.
verses.comment: Welcoming the stranger is a practice later explicitly commanded in the New Testament.

verses.text: If I have concealed my transgressions as Adam, by hiding my guilt in my heart,
verses.comment: Confession and openness with God—as opposed to self-deceit—is a recurring theme in the scriptures (see 1 John 1:9).

verses.text: because I feared the great multitude, and the contempt of families terrified me, so that I kept silent and did not go out of doors—
verses.comment: The fear of public disgrace can tempt one into silence or falsehood. True faith walks in the light.

verses.text: Oh, that I had someone to hear me! (Here is my signature; let the Almighty answer me!) Oh, that I had the indictment which my adversary has written!
verses.comment: Job’s yearning for God’s answer points toward the ultimate answer in the Incarnate Word—the Logos who intercedes for humanity.

verses.text: Surely I would carry it on my shoulder; I would bind it to myself like a crown.
verses.comment: Job is willing to face judgment boldly; the 'crown' is a symbol also echoed in New Testament rewards for fidelity (James 1:12).

verses.text: I would declare to Him the number of my steps; like a prince, I would approach Him.
verses.comment: Confidence before God—even as a ‘prince’—anticipates access to grace won by Christ.

verses.text: If my land cries out against me, and its furrows weep together,
verses.comment: Land personified as testifying against injustice recalls Abel’s blood crying out from the ground.

verses.text: if I have eaten its yield without payment, or caused the owners to lose their lives,
verses.comment: Job insists he has not exploited others—economic justice is tied to spiritual righteousness.

verses.text: let thorns grow instead of wheat, and foul weeds instead of barley.” The words of Job are ended.
verses.comment: With this curse invoking the fruitlessness associated with the Fall, Job closes his defense. His blamelessness points toward the perfect innocence of Christ, the suffering righteous one.
